--- Steven Webster <steven.webster@...> wrote:
> I've inherited a huge codebase which I'll be taking over development
> for; as soon as
> possible, I want to put skeletal JUnit tests in place for every
> class; as I perform
> refactorings, and as I introduce new functionality, my intention is
> to first flesh out
> JUnit tests, before adding feature/refactoring.
> 
> This raises several questions, most of all related to what are the
> best practices
> for keeping Unit Tests alongside code.
> 
> Options as I see them:
> 
> 1.    A separate directory tree with a root note of test, the package
> structure of
>       which reflects that of the codebase; keep the tests completely
> isolated from
>       production code, the downside being that if I refactor code
> around packages,
>       I have to remember to move tests as well; also, removes my
> ability to test
>       private and protected methods..
> 

Just to clarify, classes within the same package can access each
other's protected methods.  So, the limitation will only be on testing
private methods with this approach.  Personally, I use this approach.

Mike
